description.text:
A remix of robosavvy's access. Two oring slots,#7 and a #14, three pieces in one file, prints without raft. It is sized for 1.75mm and a guide tube should slot in the top as shown. Its meant to be a clamping arrangement with your container, #4 machine screws (or #8s if you drill out the top some), the bottom hat is meant for robosavvy's rubber glove trick.

I made this as something to print faster, without raft, to not rely on glue, could mount closer to the edge, and that would better hold my guide tubes. This works pretty well for me, I may make a Version 2 of the port with nut holders like the spool and a better fit on the glove.

The container pictured is from Container Store: Sistema 5 liter which seems to fit every spool I have. I sized my base spool holder for Taulman spools (additional spool fillers for stock FFC spools and Hatchbox spools, free cad files included). Side to side spacers may be needed, we shall see (will upload later). When drilling drill slow and use a pilot! I cracked my first hole as this Sistem is brittle. Let me know if you find a better 9in spool holder for less than $10.

Added Freecad file if you want to customize, you can tweak to your own guide tube, fastener, and o-ring sizes you have on hand. Also you can export one stl at a time if you wish.

I print all with a 20% infill it isn't structural and a few shells, 2lb spool isn't a lot of load. No raft needed.

For the spools use #8x32 pan heads and #8 nuts for best results.

description.text:
There are so many wonders in the world! Pick the wonders you like and see them on this merry-go-round.

This merry-go-round outfitted with many wonders of the modern world. All of the pictures for the 2D to 3D models were hand drawn by us. This merry-go-round can spin in two different places, the roof of the merry-go-round and the base of the merry-go-round.

There are a total of 15 wonders on our merry-go-round, 10 are mounted on the poles that are evenly spaced. The other five are laying flat on the merry-go-round's floor.

The 2D to 3D software we used is Inkscape. This merry-go-round was completely designed by us in Tinkercad.

Assembly is in the video.
Link: http://youtu.be/FdNLxLkFta8

The Roof:

The roof was printed with 3 shells,10% infill, 0.3 mm layer height, and with rafts and supports. We scaled it down to 70% to fit into the Makerbot Replicator 2. The roof took about 5 hours to print.

The Middle Layer:

The middle layer was printed with 2 shells, 10% infill, 0.2 mm layer height, and with rafts. We scaled it down to 70% percent to reduce printing time and to fit with the roof. The middle layer took about 3 and a half hours to print. We changed filament color when the printer started to print the wonders. When the printer completely finished printing the wonders and started to print the edges, we switched the filament back to the original color. You may need to tape double-sided tape onto the build plate to prevent warping.

The Bottom Layer:

The bottom layer was printed with 2 shells, 10% infill, 0.3 mm layer height, and with rafts. We scaled it down to 70% percent to reduce printing time and to fit with the middle layer. The middle layer took about 1 and a half hours to print. You may need to tape double-sided tape onto the build plate to prevent warping.

The 10 Wonders:

The 10 wonders were printed with 2 shells, 10% infill, 0.2 mm layer height, and with rafts. We scaled it down to 70% percent to reduce printing time and to fit with the poles on the roof. The 10 wonders took about 14 minutes on average to print each. When the print is 50% complete, you can change the filament to achieve a different color background.

Challenge: See The World

-Create a 3D model of an outdoor landmark from around the world, either from a place you're visiting this summer, or a place you've always wanted to visit.

My parents are both from Romania, so I thought it would be nice to find a cool Hungarian looking castle from my parents homeland; a place I have always wanted to visit. I found this really amazing Romanian Castle named "Corvin Castle". Corvin Castle is a Gothic-Renaissance castle in Hunedoara, Romania. It is one of the largest castles in Europe and one of the seven wonders of Romania. It is designed after the famous castle in Budapest, Hungary, named Vajdahunyad Castle.

Using a lot of reference images and a floor plan, I created this model using 3ds Max and mesh mixer. I learned a lot building this model, and created the model so it print's without any supports! Enjoy!

For more information on Corvin Castle:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corvin_Castle

description.text:
Inching closer to perfection. This thing is an update to the revoloids library. This time around, I've gotten the normals calculated correctly, so that a 'shell_extrude' can be performed. So, now there are two methods in the revoloids.scad file: linear_extrude_revoloid, shell_extrude_revoloid The first one will 'intrude' towards the center of rotation. that's a nice valid way of doing things, but the ends must be relatively flat or things will get messed up. The shell_extrude, which is new here, will 'do the needful' and extrude inward, or outward, based on the normals at the points on the curves (circule, and cubic curve). That's useful in some cases, and you'll get a uniform thickness across the piece. There's some nice 'visual debug' support, so you can see fancy colors, wireframes, normals, and the like (exhibited in the attached pictures). And yes, it does in fact generate valid .stl files (exhibited in the attached .stl files). What more can be done with this? Well, I took the opportunity to remove the implementation of the bezier surface of revolution, because it is now redundant. I would like to do piecewise curves with C0/C1 continuity. It's just a matter of stitching them together. That will allow for more complex shapes. Other than that, not much other than some more simplifications, and rotation around an arbitrary axis. But, perhaps that can wait for a 2.0 version. Still need to work on convenient end caps Ultimately I'll merge this into the Renderer.scad file BEWARE:
Your ends should NOT be totally vertical
Hermite curves still don't come out quite correctly UPDATE: 270611
I figured out my Hermite problem. The actual problem relates to the cheap way in which I am still calculating the normal to the circle. You absolutely MUST create your curve in the x-y plane. It will be interesting at some point to add the ability to do it more free form, but for now, it's best if your curve is planar in the x-y

1) Download all the .scad files
2) Play with test_revoloids.scad
3) Look at the pretty pictures
4) Generate .stl
5) Rejoice!

title: Printrbot Plus Quick-Fit Upgrade v1/v2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The easiest way to upgrade your Printrbot Plus to Richrap's quick fit system by only replace the topplate of the original extruder mount. You are still able to mount the original extruder without mounting the old topplate, or mount it with the supplied adapter the quick fit way. During extruder development I like this solution, because I can easily switch back to a working extruder. Update v2 Modifications
  • Integreated M3 threads to mount extensions like fans or Z end stops
  • Stronger adapter plate for the original extruder
  • Easier to print in separate parts, glued/melted togehter with acetone (works with ABS only)

Assembly
  • Print the needed parts
  • v2 only: Glue/Melt the house onto the topplate with acetone
  • v2 only: Put in the five M3 nuts and fill up with in acetone disolved ABS
  • Dismount the original extruder and topplate
  • Countersink the two holes (see photo 2)
  • Mount the latch to the topplate with the two bearings, 30mm screw, two washers and lock nut.
  • Mount the topplate to the Printrbot Plus with the four 10mm screws and nuts
    • Adapter (optional):
  • Countersink the two holes in the adapter (the screws should not stick out!)
  • v2 only: Glue/Melt the reinforcement to the adapter with acetone
  • Mount the adapter plate to the extruder
    • BOM
  • 1x printed topplate (v2: topplate and house)
  • 1x printed latch by Richrap
  • 4x M4x10mm flat (countersink) head screws
  • 4x M4 nuts
  • 2x 624 bearings
  • 1x M4x30mm screw
  • 2x M4 washers
  • 1x M4 lock nut
  • 5x M3 nut (v2 only)
    • Adapter (optional):
  • 1x printed adapter (v2: adapter and reinforcement)
  • 2x M4x16mm flat (countersink) head screws
  • 2x M4 nuts

description.text:
UPDATE 1/6/15 Version 3 finished (interchangeable upper and lowers with version 2, but three is best all around). Less material as it was a bit overly beefy, better support for the container with an adjustable side to side bracket to easily fit 2 on a printer, better fastener options. Better shim that clips in to prevent rotation. Container now held securely. This is done, it works, maybe in the future a V4 or for aesthetics only.

Use a filament container setup, mine is located here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:962258

V2 shown in green(vs V_1 in orange it is more printer friendly, less time, sturdy). Comes with source files, anti-rotation shim. Works/prints better than V1, just needs a rubber band to hold container snug against bracket, version 3 is more elegant. Let me know if you have further suggestions.

This is a sealed container holder mount for the slot type FFC Pro filament spool mounts. My containers need to be mounted to the printer itself as my bookshelf it is on has no other options, and I really like the idea of keeping the filament sealed with a moisture absorber (desiccant).

I will post the V4 freecad files when finished, V2 available for now.

This is made with 3 shells and 10% infill ABS, print raftless, pieces press together on V1 bolt together on V2, 3. V3 I have been using 2 shells with 10% infill PLA, raftless.

V2 use countersunk screws, V1 just fill the holes with plugs. PLA should work fine with fewer shells on version two with the taller rails. The anti-rotation goes over the top to stop rotation, the container holds the plug snug if you tie against the bracket.

comments.text: Cake tins are a good idea as you can pop off one side and leave the other attached to the machine.  Let me know if you find one appropriately sized for a spool and I will help model a hangar.  I have a bunch of the little baggies of silica, and my large container for spool not inuse uses a large silica bead can and a wireless dehumidifier (also silica).  I get to 20% humidity with the separate storage with one little bag, and 5% in my larger not in use container, in a room at 34% humidity.  I have a port mount based on robosavvy's idea if you search by my id, but mine is meant to bolted.  I tried glue only, but vertically mounted it proved to not be baby thrown proof.

Uneven Floor?
Need a Wedge?
Make one which fits your floor!

How to measure:

1. Measure slope length,

normally from one leg to the second leg alongside the slope.

2. Measure the gap

a) put a spirit level on-top of the surface so the spirit level end is above the leg at the higher end of the slope.  
b) lift the spirit level, until level, at the leg on the lower side of the slope.  
c) measure the gap above the lower leg, between surface and spirit level.

3. Decide about the block size of the wedge.

The wedge should be slightly bigger than the foot.

4. You might want to have an edge around

It can prevent slipping off the wedge. Decide on width of the edge and it's height.

Printing Instructions:

Work in Progress:

I printed the block in place, meaning there is a gap to the printing platform and it has to be supported.

The idea behind is:

the top surface is a bit rough to make it less slippery.
the bottom surface is really rough after the the support is removed, which will make sure to keep the wedge in place.

Printing it upside down, gives nicer the wedge a nicer bottom,
and is still rough enough not to slip.
Note: if printed with edge, an upside down print requires good gap spanning, support material is difficult to remove. So I printed it without support.

Infill

40% infill will support heavy item,
Bar fridge, with 3 18l kegs,stays on 30% infill, without issues.

I created Dry Tortugas National Park, the most isolated national park in the United States, also the most remote island in the Florida Keys. I used Tinkercad to create this park. It took me a day and a half to create it. I kept on messing up because this is one of the first designs I created on Tinkercad. I started by placing a hexagon for Fort Jefferson which is an unfinished. Construction for the fort started in 1847. While creating this I was feeling stressed and kept messing up. I kept feeling it didn’t look good enough, but I reminded myself that everything has flaws even the real landmark. I added texture along with the land that surrounded the fort. It started to look more like Dry Tortugas. It’s still not completely perfect but the most beautiful art has plenty of mistakes, but it ends up fine. I kept on fixing the walls on the fort to make it look more like it had been when I had seen it. I have been there and it is a beautiful place. I feel kind of mad that I couldn’t really add anything inside the fort or it would’ve disappeared. However, when I visited the park the outside was just as beautiful as the inside. Since I couldn’t add anything inside I tried to make the outside as beautiful as possible. It turned out just the way I had planned.
to see the tinkercad file follow the link below.
https://www.tinkercad.com/search/?q=Fort+Jefferson%2FDry+Tortugas+National+Park
To get the best results you will need to have .1 mm layer heights. You will need supports. To print in full size you will need a large printer.

description.text: Rocket Trophy/Statue Template. Feel free to change it and put your name on it! :)

I have completely upgraded the r.250 FPV Quad by quadmodder. I fly my quad fast and crash hard. I was tired of the same parts breaking in the same locations. I also increased the width of the body so I could put all four ESCs on top of the bottom plate to protect them. The width addition brings this quad in at just under 300mm. I added a frame around the perimeter to reduce frame twist, I also added gussets to the screw holes that had the highest failure rate. The arms have been redesigned to maximize strength and reduce twist. I have not broken an arm since this modification.

I used to use PET to make this quad for increased strength and dimensional stability, but since I made these changes to the frame I have switched back to ABS. ABS prints just as well for me on my PowerSpec 3D Pro (OEM FlashForge Pro).

comments.text: Let me know how it works out for you.  I normally cut the r.250 out of carbon fiber.  I didnt draw it, I just adapted it to 3d printing.  If you fly as hard as you say you do, you'll need carbon fiber.  I got tired of ripping quads apart too.  I've flown almost every major frame in here.  They all suffer from the same thing.  I only see minor edits to the frame, and the arms look like dji arms.  Were there any other changes to the total redraw?
comments.author: quadmodder

comments.text: The edits I made to this frame have increased the durability for me.  The material addition to the areas around where the hardware passes through the frame addressed a majority of the frame failures.  The addition of the brim around the frame added a significant resistance to frame twist.  The arms are more like the Spyda 500 than a DJI.  The arm design added resistance to twist and fracture strength to the junction of the motor mount and arm neck.  That location is where I would see breakage on hard landings and crashes.  I also added counterbore reliefs under the SHCS for a more aesthetic look.  The width increase also lets you tuck the ESCs into the frame envelope for protection.  The feet are breaking on occasion but they are easy to print and replace.  There will always be a trade off between strength and weight.

title: DJI Phantom 3 & Inspire 1 Range Extender – Version E

description.text:
This version “E” of my original Range Extender (Thingiverse#961197) is a moderate modification, and the primary difference is that the Parabolic Arches on this version are considerably deeper. In general, this makes the ‘focus’ of the Range Extender narrower, or ‘sharper’, while the overall gain is increased. However, this requires the operator to pay close attention to the direction of the quadcopter and to keep the controller and Antennas carefully pointed in its direction. As shown in the photos, this version also fits the Controller very well, with plenty of space to tilt the Antennas and Range Extender to various angles.

This easy-to-print Range Extender will extend the range of your Phantom 3 or Inspire 1 considerably. It slips onto the standard un-modified DJI Controller Antennas and can be quickly installed or removed with one hand – even when your quadcopter is airborne.

The Range Extender was created with accurate, deep parabolic curves, and with the antenna mounts centered at each parabolic focal point to maximize signal gain and overall effectiveness.

The only consideration for using this parabolic reflector effectively (and any other high-gain antenna, for that matter) is that you ensure your antenna is directly facing the quadcopter. Thanks to DJI, that’s pretty easy, even when your quadcopter may be out of your direct sight. Simply note the position of the green line that appears on your DJI Pilot or DJI GO application map that runs between where you are standing and where the quadcopter is currently located on the map, and turn your controller to face directly up that green line towards the quadcopter. That strategy will ensure maximum antenna gain and the longest possible range for both control of the quadcopter and transmission of the FPV feed.

I’ve tested this DJI Phantom 3 / Inspire 1 Range Extender with my Phantom 3 Pro, and it works very well, delivering considerably more maximum effective range. Please note that no antenna range extender works well through heavy cover (such as through dense forests) or from behind large solid objects (such as behind hills or large buildings). Best performance will always be obtained with a line-of-sight signal path between the controller and quadcopter – even when the quadcopter is beyond your visual range. If you pay close attention to the Remote Controller Signal Strength Indicator and the HD Video Link Signal Strength Indicator, you’ll know exactly how strong your signal is, and you’ll be able to determine when you are reaching the limits of your range.

All parts print without support, and require very little post-print finishing. Both the Parabolic Reflector Shell and the Antenna Mounts have been designed to be as thin and lightweight as possible, while still ensuring adequate strength and durability. Total Finished Weight= 50.75 grams.

Please share your Makes and any suggestions you have for improvements.

Print all the parts: 1 Parabolic Base, and 2 each of the Top and Bottom Mounts. I used the following settings on my MakerBot Replicator 5th Generation: PLA; Standard Profile; Infill=25%; Layer Height=0.20mm; Infill Layer Height=0.20mm; Shells=3; Raft=Yes; Supports=No. Print times were approximately: 7 hours for the Parabolic Base (49g filament) and 50 minutes (6g filament) for the Set of 4 Antenna Mounts.

Additional parts required for assembling the Range Extender (which I purchased at Home Depot):
• 4 each #4x3/8” Pan Head Sheet Metal Screws (~$1.18 / 8).
Note: each of these screws must be shortened to ~1/4” by filing or sanding. If the threads are longer than 1/4” they will protrude into the antenna mount – not good!
• 1 each Reflectix Multi-Purpose FOIL TAPE FT210 – 2” x 30’.
Note: Another Thingiverse contributor found 4” wide foil tape on Amazon which would be a perfect size for this project. You may want to consider that alternative although I thought I might have trouble working with such large pieces.

Assembly:
First, cut two pieces of the Foil Tape, each slightly longer than necessary to cover the full width of the Parabolic Base (about 25cm each). Remove a little over half the backing on the first piece. Then, center the first piece near the top of the Base (about 1mm from the top edge); ensure that both ends of the foil are ‘square’ with the top edge of the Base. Then, working from the center towards one outside edge, slowly stick down and smooth the first foil piece down and across to the outside edge. Make sure the foil wraps slightly around the outside edge and leave the excess for now. Try to avoid creases or ‘bubbles’ as you install the foil.

Second, remove the backing from the other side of the first foil piece, and smooth it down over the second side, again taking care to keep it aligned about 1mm down from the top edge of the Base. Again, make sure the foil wraps slightly around the outside edge and leave the excess for now.

Third, follow the same general steps for the bottom half of the Parabolic Base. Try hard to have the top and bottom foils meet as close as possible, but not overlap.

Forth, take some time to smooth the foil across the complete Parabolic Base, removing any bubbles or wrinkles, and sharpening the center spine as much as possible. The smoother the foil is, the better the reflector will perform.

Fifth, take a razor blade or very sharp knife and cut off the excess foil along both outside edges, leaving just enough to smooth around the outside edges with your fingernail.

Now, ‘punch’ out each screw hole from the front (foil) side of the Parabolic Base. You may also want to enlarge each of the 4 Parabolic Reflector holes slightly (to around 3mm) so that the Screws will just barely slide through the holes smoothly.

Then, set one Bottom Mount on a flat surface, smooth, rounded side up, and push the Parabolic Base up to it on the foil side, right side up; push the first Screw (see note above about shortening the screws!) through the back of the Base and up to the Bottom Mount, carefully holding the parts together. I held the Mount down with my thumb and pushed it hard against the Base with my knuckle. It may help to turn the Screw forward half a turn, then back a little bit, then forward again, repeating as you go – this will reduce the effort required to install the screws. Assemble the second Bottom Mount in the same manner.

Finally, turn the Parabolic Base upside down and install the 2 Top Mounts (upside down) in the same manner as above. Assembling the Mounts in this manner will ensure that they are aligned correctly. Take a look at the gaps between the Antenna Mounts and the foil tape and further tighten any screws which are not fully seated. Correct vertical alignment of the Antenna Mounts will ensure that the Range Extender will slide on and off the DJI Controller easily.

Test the Range Extender on your DJI Controller, and make any necessary adjustments to the alignment of the Mounts. You may also need to file the inside of each mount slightly to clean up any stray filament and remove any rough edges.

Have Fun! Fly Safe!

title: Screw and knob for Thingiverse Platform Jack #925556

description.text: I tried printing out the platform jack on my printer several times and, despite finally breaking free everything I could, kept twisting off the knob. This is a stand-alone screw and knob assembly to replace the printed in place assembly and can be used if you've broken the other moving parts free but have twisted off the knob. Some test pieces are included to allow you to scale the knob to get the screw end to fit.

Use the test pieces to scale the knob for the threads and material you are using. The jackscrew was a 3/8" threaded rod and seemed to fit the printout as is, the knob screw did not. I used 120% scaling on the knob to get it to thread on, your material may require a different scaling. You will need to rotate the test knob 180 degrees to get it to print on the knob end rather than the threaded end. Same is true of the knob.

These were printed in ABS at 0.1 mm layer height

The gear scripts are Matlab scripts to create curves for involute gears. These scripts create an x-y path for gears given the diametral pitch series, pitch angle, number of teeth, gear height, and a few other characteristics. My main reference for creating these gears is the Machinery Handbook pg 1995 to 2010, and the McMaster Carr catalog (which has examples for different pitch series). [1] [2].

The paths can then be used to create stl files for spur gears.

title: Raspberry Pi B+ Sleeve Case Stand

description.text:
I needed a decent stand for my Octoprint RasPi and I love the sleeve case designs. Didn't take me too long to design this in TinkerCad, but the good thing about this stand is that it fits nice and snug without obscuring the Micro USB on the side too much.

The case I used is based off of Walter's design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:604915), so chances are there's plenty more out there that this will work with.

I printed mine on a Printrbot Simple Metal, 2mm layer height, 3 shells, 20% infill using Hatchbox PLA in about 28 minutes. I don't have a heated bed installed, so these settings worked great to minimize the amount of curl on the legs - It still stands nice and stable!

A 3D Printed Quad Copter by Bad-Intel and Cyberpunk V2.0 .
This Is version 2.0 of the quadcopter.

From: http://www.cyber-punk.info

Improvements:
Stronger Motor and Landing mount.
Reinforced canopy covers

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ra6kpXIz6wo

All parts are attached together with aluminum square tube.

The 3D printed parts should slot into the aluminum square tube.

Requires drilling, nuts and bolts to put it all together. The holes to be drilled are already part of the 3D print and just need to be drilled out to size.

I use two body plates to extend the length of the copter. But for smaller copters, just use one body plate.

The front has a hole for a CCD camera, while the back has a hole for a antenna to fit.

The unit in the photo uses 4x MT2213-935KV MultiStar Motors with a 4S 6000mah battery. (Gives me about 45 mins flying time)

Will publish the canopy and all terrain landing gear soon.

For personal use only.
Copyright of http://www.bad-intel.com and http://www.cyber-punk.com

description.text: as title

The Thinker is one of the most renowned pieces of art in the world, and an overall magnificent sculpture. this model offers knowledge to students about important art in the world, and can gain knowledge of 3d printing by understanding and experimenting with supports to understand some of the principles of 3d printing. Try experiment with different layer heights and resolutions for best results. The print you see above is 0.1 mm layer height. Enjoy an post some prints if possible thanks.
The Thinker (French: Le Penseur) is a bronze sculpture by Auguste Rodin, usually placed on a stone pedestal. There is male figure of a large size sitting on a rock with his chin resting on one hand as though deep in thought, and is often used as an image to represent philosophy. Multiple adaptations have been made. Enjoy!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1

Download file.
Make sure it is flat on platform. Try with and without supports. Avoid Rafts. Use high resolution.
Take it to your slicing software and print.
Leave a comment :)

Laser beam Target to fit a Universal M300 laser to align the laser beam.
The Laser I have is an old > 10 years used laser cutter The problem seen was push fit bearing holes were not straight so bearings did not fit vertical to the board surface see pic of single bearing.
I noticed that the Lense assembly had a secondary counter bore around the laser hole  made a target to fit the counter bore to alow laser alignment using the red spot laser / Lid open mode.
Push fit bearings now sit parallel after laser adjustment using the target

author: fay

title: Corsair K70 Wrist Rest Clip Replacement

description.text:
I had broken the clips that hold the wrist rest for my Corsair K70 RGB keyboard, probably due to the fact that I don't have a proper desk so the keyboard goes on my lap and occasionally falls. So I whipped up this design and 3d printed the much stronger replacements. The old clips also tended to slip out very easily, these don't have that problem (while still moving/conforming smoothly).

The print required some supports so it came out kind of ugly, but it still functions perfectly! To install I marked where the holes needed to be drilled and used short 2-56 screws and nuts. The holes are sized for 2-56, 100 degree pan head SS milspec screws I sourced from mcmaster (Part #: 90471a115). There was barely enough space behind the plastic for the 2-56 nuts so I doubt any bigger screws/nuts will work.

These are for the K70 RGB version but it seems that Corsair's whole line of mechanical keyboards are very similar in build so it may even work for the other models with less/more keys.

To install I marked where the holes needed to be drilled and used short 2-56 screws and nuts. The holes are sized for 2-56, 100 degree pan head SS milspec screws I sourced from mcmaster (Part #: 90471a115). There was barely enough space behind the plastic for the 2-56 nuts so I doubt any bigger screws/nuts will work.

comments.text: I'm getting really bad curling on the base of this model, to the point that I never get past the base layer, because the extruder eventually just catches and mangles the material. I'm using PLA on a non-heated bed on a Monoprice Maker Architect and I level the platform as well as I can before each print. I've been using a 3M sheet that is similar to the BuildTak 3D printing surface, and while it's worked really well for smaller prints, it was unable to prevent the curling in this case. title: RAMBo Frame for Prusa i3 Hephestos

description.text:
You will need five 3mm x 10mm bolts.

The slots in the crossmember should hold the RAMBo Frame and Prusa Bracket parts with a very snug pressfit alone. You can use glue if you wish, but it should not be necessary. This will depend on your print settings, of course, and I am willing to provide my Cura profile for PLA if you need it. I printed these parts on my Hephestos with the default PLA settings, except updated for the correct nozzle size.

I wasn't quite satisfied with the flexing and movement of some of the autolevel brackets I found, so decided to design my own. This uses the existing screws that hold the fan and heatsink to the extruder and mounts just under the heatsink. Please Note that when I designed this part, I neglected to add an offset to the part... thus, where it needs to be 10 mm, it's exactly 10mm. So as it currently sits, the part needs a bit of "persuasion" to fit correctly. Mostly just sanding, as I made it a bit too exact, and should have taken off a quarter millimeter or something to make the fit a bit easier.
Added the Arm I'm using. It's a mash of 2 other arms... I'll look around later for the sources that this is based off of.

author: vicpino

title: Lens cap holder screwed to camera bottom

description.text:
There exist already many lens cap holders, but most of them are attached to the camera strap. I found this not so practical, since when I hold the camera, remove the lens cap and try to clip it to the holder, the strap is moving and it's not so easy to hit the right spot. So my lens cap holder is different: it attaches firmly to the bottom of the camera via a bolt screwed into the standard tripod mounting thread. By default, this lens cap holder is dimensioned for my Canon PowerShot SX-40, which has a lens cap diameter of 50mm.
The SCAD file, however, can easily be adapted to any other lens cap size. Also, I found that on my reprap printer the thread widths had to be slightly decreased to fit, so I had to
finetune it by setting correction term "corr=0.01" in the .scad file.

remixed_from.title: Two Up Upper Z Rod Guide mounts (For 8mm Linear Rods)

title: QUBD : Bearing holder to prevent z-rod wobbling

description.text:
This is redesign and mix of
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:289966
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:754526

The changes are

  • Instead of the 608zz ball bearing, I use the flange bearing. as my local HomeDepot had stock.
    http://www.homedepot.com/p/Crown-Bolt-3-8-in-x-5-8-in-x-1-in-Bronze-Flange-Bearing-57738/203537359
    I hope this longer shelve provides the z-rod even less room to tilt.

  • Instead of bridging very long lid (40[mm]), I separate them into 2 parts (body and cap) to sandwich the handle bar (PART:SS) with m3 screws.

  • Arrange a pocket on the bottom (2nd picture), to keep the maximum travel z-distance of my gantry. (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:952796 )

  • Instead of drilling the stock MDF part, I use the sandwich mechanism to attached the body to the handle bar.

The results are ---

  • x:surface : The jagging significantly reduced. Almost disappeared. AMAZING !!
    Although it's hard to take pictures representing my surprise, the 3rd picture is my best effort without a macro lens ( from top -- with this bracket, 2nd and 3rd without )
    Or the result looks like this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:938425 (from different design)

  • y:surface : A little jagging still observed ( I think I need to improve the y-table controls the other day)

Also, I don't see the handle bar shift any more.

Print 1 pcs of body and 2 pcs of caps. Sandwich them with M3 x 20 screws and nuts as shown in the picture.

If you print them with the original Oneup/Twoup, you might find the holes for the bearing and z-rod are very tight. Use the hobby knife or rasp to widen it. Once installed, reprint the body. I hope you will be amazed as much as I was how the print quality improved and the reprinted object fits smoothly without rasping.

author: rliae

title: openbuilds 8mm Metric Acme Lead Screw i3 pgrade

description.text:
I'm using the modified z rod spacing (further from build plate/zmotor) from thing:289720.

these will fit the octagonal nut plate you can get for:

  • http://openbuildspartstore.com/8mm-metric-acme-lead-screw/
  • http://openbuildspartstore.com/nut-plate-for-8mm-metric-acme-lead-screw/

features include:

  • Compact design compatible with standard i3 geometries, as long as you print the zmotor mounts and upper zrod mounts by daftscience
  • Tensioner for the x axis belt
  • Motor on right side of printer (left as viewed from front)
  • Chamfered hole geometry for easy insertion of kapton-covered rods
  • Chamfered hole geometry for the nut plate
  • Easy zbearing clamp (idler/tensioner end) designed for ABS plastics and similar.

At this point I'm editing dimensions for how tight things fit and stuff like that. one part i'm worried about is squeezing the leadscrew nuts too tightly and having the rod holes set up right.
need to assemble a set and check clearances on the hardware for the idler.

todo:

  • still testing stiffness [update: stiffness is good with new geometry]
  • Still need to test clamp, might need to be thicker or something. [update: seems to work well, even in ABS. takes a tool (i use 11mm socket) to push lm8uu into place/remove]
  • will change motor end soon to make it print with less support [maybe not, not a big deal]
  • might also have a motor end that prints without support [not that important, no issues with support]
  • might play with motor end design [forgot where I was going with this...]
  • might add a mounting bracket to mount things like webcams [mmmmn yes.... ] or filament break detectors [would probably need to be mounted somewhere else]
  • thinking about beefing up the upper zrod mounts and designing one for 10mm zrods. cuz like, why not? those lead screws aren't that expensive haha. [won't be doing this because 10mm rods are pretty expensive, and I don't really have stiffness issues]

remixed_from.title: NES Raspberry Pi B+ Case for Printrbot 1405

description.text:
I didn't like the fit and finish on other raspberry pi NES style cases, so I made my own! It took several iterations before I was happy with it, and I think it's good enough to share now! While I didn't use anyone else's designs for the case and made it from scratch in autodesk inventor 2016, even though it looks like some others on here.

It uses a peg system to align the top and bottom halves and to keep the Pi in place. There are no clips used and you don't need screws to keep it together. It just uses the tightness of the dimensions to stay together but can easily be pried apart with a small screwdriver to get to the Pi board. That being said, depending on how dimensionally accurate your printer is, you may have to sand down the pegs, enlarge the holes, etc. to get it to fit.

I printed mine in PLA, 200*c with 0.2 mm layers. Some sanding or opening holes may be required to get the halves to fit. Many people that have built this recommend to increase the lid length by 2-3%. This was not needed for me to print it, but it may help for others.

author: sclslib

description.text:
This is basically the same thing as the one by RichMac without spacers and resized. I ported the files over to AlibreCAD, and resized it all for a 3mm shaft. I also made the rotors use hex insets, so 3mm locknuts provide the torque. This may not provide useful amounts of power, but it sure is effective in just making it spin. No spacers needed, just three or four 623 bearings two or four 3mm locknuts, and at least 35mm of 3mm socket cap screw - but that short and nothing sticks out. 50mm+ recommended.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K5l5G1aihk I had a smaller vacuum too so now it fits on a 28mm wide hose.

I'm still working out if this provides usable torque or if the spacer design of the original is needed.  Adding a way to get power out is needed to test that...  Also still working on the screw threads in AlibreCAD after all my re-sizing.  
Print 2x rotors, 1x stator, 1 each housing.  Press a 623 bearing in each housing and the center stator. Press locknuts into both rotors.  Push the axle through the front stator housing.  Thread a rotor as far down as it will go without scraping when rotated. Slide center stator in place (wide side away from the stator housing), then screw the next rotor on similarly to the first. Slide/screw the top housing in place and test that it can freely rotate.  Spin by hand and you should feel some air come out.  
Attach to vacuum and annoy any cats that happen to be around.

author: Roberts3D

title: Counter Rotating Propellers - proof of concept v.1

description.text:
For now, this is just a proof of concept of how couter rotating propellers can be driven. There are no complete mechanics to print yet. I am working on it.

Version 1: Movement goes in at the red axle on the right, and through the hollow green axle. The Movement is reversed by the blue beveled gear and goes out through the green axle.

Version 1a: Movement goes in through the blue axle and drives the red and green gears and their axles in opposite directions.

See: https://youtu.be/0EKPofeld98

Update
As all thing are subjected to change and a better mouse traps to come along. One has. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14747 Itâ€™s been a month since I bout my Thing-O-Matic (TOM). After the first two weeks the belt on my Automatic Build Platform (ABP) was pretty warped from all the stuff I was printing.
So I wanted to be able to place the Heat Build Platform (HBP) on it and save the belts on the ABP. But it was a pain to change them out. The few examples I did find here ether required you to cut into your brand new TOM or buy some new parts. So I made my own setup. The requirement was to stick with the original part that came with TOM and not to slice and dice any of the parts up. (Since you never know when someone else comes along with a better mouse trap}
This is the design I came up with it reuses all of the original part except a second heat platform http://store.makerbot.com/makerbot-thingomatic-heater-board-v1-1.html . Unless you decide to use the non-heated platform. I have left the "work in progress" on since I think this can have some more improvements. Like something better then the clamps I used on it. This should save on the belts on the ABP. UpDate
If you already put one together and there are no problems with it then there is no need to print them out again. All I did was clean up the models. I also added a derivative of the roller bearing option for thaws who need or want it.
For more info on that go to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8625
There are two images to show you how it goes together. It is pretty safe to assume you have put together the original X platform that this should be no problem.

This is an extruder cable chain I remixed and made to suit the DaVinci 1.0 printer. It has a mounting bar to attach it to the extruder which can be simply glued or screwed in place.
The .stl contains a full set needed of 32 links, the clips and the mounting piece.
I just used double sided tape to attach the printer end of the cable just under the topmost metal piece at the back, and it works best if you reverse the bend direction on the last 10 or 11 links closest to the extruder to get proper orientation and clearance whilst printing.
I also suggest that you cut the link on the mounting piece to allow a full 180 degree pivot, that helps to allow the chain to move smoothly.
I am using a Mk8 hex extruder but this chain should happily fit the standard extruder as well.

comments.author: Boogiemann

comments.text:
Hi, the extruder upgrade is quite easy.
Its a mk8 hex head extruder assembly, they're readily available online for around $60.
The best part is that it basically is a straight swap. The heater and temp sensor from the original will fit straight into the new head. The original stepper fits but you will need to remove the gear and use the mk8 gear, and you will need to drill one of the mounting screw holes in the mk8 a bit deeper so the screws will bite into the stepper, and the holes in the fan need to be recessed deeper to allow the original fan to allow it to fit.
If you want to make your davinci a real good machine from a novelty, this is the go.
You can choose nozzle sizes and print in abs, pla, pet, rubber, bronzefill etc etc.
If you look at my post on the voltivo davinci forum called "davinci good to great for under $200" you will see all the simple mods you can do to get a really professional machine.
comments.author: Boogiemann

comments.text: Thanks! I can't believe it's that easy! I'm kicking myself right now. I've been spending a ton of time trying to either convert it to a bowden system or fit a J-style tip! I actually bought an aluminum mk8 already! Just found the kit. I think all I need is to get a v5 heatbreak, and I'm in business! Thanks for the tip! I've been trying to get the stock tip to print nylon. This might just do it!
comments.author: Madazz01

comments.text:
The other main thing is calibration, you need to use a slicer that you can set layer heights and then set it to print and switch it off as it starts the first layer and manually calibrate it. I use slic3r and set it to 0.4 but i have a feeler guage that is 0.37, then i move the print head over each screw and set it pefectly with the guage.
The 0.03 lower gives you better adhesion on the first layer and adjusting above all 3 screws make for perfect calibration, much more accurate than the auto calibration.
comments.author: Boogiemann

comments.text:
Hi it really is that easy, you don't need a heatbreak with the teflon lined tube.
The other big mistake I think everyone makes with the davinci is thinking hotter is better, its wrong.
Take 10% off the print temp on the filament and it'll print like a dream, for example for abs first layer 225, all the rest 215, you just want it melted enough to bond properly but not ooze and get messy.
You can print PLA all day at 180 and just so the machine has time to settle, set the bed to 40.
For ABS you want bed temp at 90 with glue, but I actually use a 3mm alloy plate I made with kapton on it and that prints perfect at 100, never lifts, no messy glue.
Hope that helps.
comments.author: Boogiemann

comments.text: I haven't printed ABS forever now. I've been printing PLA at 190 and cold bed with glue. I do have a fan on it. I've been extremely happy with that. As for nylon, I think I'm running into a combination of the tip not being able to handle the heat and extruder being bit weak. I was able to print PC just fine.
comments.author: Madazz01

comments.text:
Trust me direct stepper drive and teflon is the way to go, you will never stop getting jams without teflon and if you stay withing the temps you will never damage the teflon. It acts as a nice smoith guide as well.
Look at how much time and effort people go to to cool things down that they have really just overheated.
I run 20 hour prints no problems with a teflon tube and no fans or heatsinks and never changed it, because like I said the big misconception with the temps is that hotter is better, when you actually want to be as cold as possible just allowing fo layer bonding.
You will find that no filament needs to go over 225 and you will get smoother, less stringy, non-oozy layers at lower temps.
The idea is start at like 210 and play with it, but i've found over much use that davinci loves 10% lower than specified temps, like i said, flawless prints every time with abs at 225 first layer then 215 for the rest. Print speed at about 35mm/s max and layers ant 0.2,
Pla likes 180 and doesnt get too runny, i've printed 5hrs of brassfill at 180 happy as.
Obviously every printer is slightly different but that will get you going nice right out of the box.
comments.author: Boogiemann

comments.text: Thanks for the tip! I've already ordered the all metal heatbreak. I'll get some teflon filled ones as well. I'd rather stay lower in temperature if possible. That's the main reason I don't bother with heated bed anymore for PLA. I might give 180 minus fan a try. 190 plus fan has been giving me close to true dimension for external measurements. Holes are a different story. This whole thing has been bothering me so much that I'm starting to look at getting another printer completely. Your mod might just save me some serious money!
comments.author: Madazz01

comments.text:
You definately need to make the bearing style x axis belt tensioner.
You can find it on thingiverse.
Could fix out of round circles, made mine more precise on corners and circles etc.

In factory condition, they have a rubber "clutch" or coupler between the drive shaft and the gearbox.
I assume this is a protection system or anti-vibration feature.

Never the less, it looks like something that will need to be replaced.
To that end I created a replacement, designed to print with ABS.
If you wish to print with PLA, You will need to adjust the tolerances a little.

Autocad, and Inventor files are also included.
The coupler is 5.7mm thick,

This model is a replica of the famous LJ12A3 inductive probe.
We also provided the .RSDOC cad file that can be opened using DesignSpark Mecanical.

This probe is used by default on all Scalar Family 3D printers.

Have a great printing experience!

author: ianmac

title: Vintage Radio Mod kit for Raycophone Peewee

description.text:
Everything you need to turn a Raycophone Peewee (AKA Racophone)
into a modern speaker box. Including the knobs!

Yes I know, I can hear you now "that's sacrilege" and that's what the historical radio buffs all told me.

This forms part of a light and sound show for the Gippsland Armed Forces Museum, and is attached to the audio system, so that parts of the show can be broadcast on a vintage radio cabinet.

Designed to adapt a speaker into the cabinet, along with a "champ amp" 0.5w amplifier kit from Jaycar (cat no: KC5152)

The frame can be installed and/or removed without permanent modification to the cabinet, and without damage.

should you attempt this mod and wish to fit a chassis at a later date, it is a simple matter of removing 4 bolts.

the knobs are my own design, as best I could model from the existing photos.

All source files are included to assist you in getting the most authentic finish.

I dipped my knobs in acetone for 20 seconds and then allowed to dry upright on the shaft of a modern dual gang trimpot by the fire.

NOTE: INVENTOR FRAME PARTS ARE NOT CORRECT!
these were made to test fit my initial 2d drawings, and the drawings were then corrected based on the test fit in inventor.
You will need to re-build the 3d parts for accuracy

I advise using a paper cone speaker for more authentic sound.
I also used 3mm MDF for the frame, later I found that 3mm plywood gives a richer sound (slightly) secure bolts firmly for a clean sound.

Any questions, leave a comment.
Video here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eWhhljf_zRo

author: Dranoweb

description.text:
A candle insert for the Skull Lantern (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:482307)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ExqqrC4wbEs&feature=youtu.be
(Flickering looks better in real life, sorry for potato quality).

The Skull Lantern was originally made to have a tea-light led candle put into the top, but I wanted to have an actual candle look to the display so I made this large candle insert which fits in the bottom of the lantern.

The shaft of the candle is a (crudely) resized, cropped version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:376176 - I'm no artist so a shout out to jradcoolness for that one.

The base of the candle is in 2 parts and has discrete openings where you can put a switch, a micro USB socket for charging a battery, and a light dependant resistor.

There is enough room to fit an LIR2032 lithium-ion battery, a charging/protection board ( http://sparks.gogo.co.nz/1A-Single-Cell-Li-Ion-Charger---With-Protection-383.html - adjusted to reduce the charge current of course, just hot-glue it in), and a PCB for the flickering LED circuit, although I've only filled it with the flickering PCB at the moment.

A standard 5mm led (or two) can be inserted in the middle of the candle and one of them comes out the top. I use a yellow and an orange LED with the yellow one poking out the top and the orange one providing an internal diffuse lighting for the candle body (printed in white pla). This produces a really nice effect - but not a lot of light, decoration, not in any way useful as a lantern!

skull-candle.dch = DipTrace Schematic
job_5843-DipTraceSchematic-_skull-candle.pdf = PDF of schematic
CandleFlicker_ATTINY13.zip = Arduino program (sketch) for ATTiny13 candle flickering
core13_with_boards_txt.zip = "core13" with my boards.txt for the Arduino IDE to support ATTiny13

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/g9yCYAOtdwB

Very similar to this model : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:962622
It's a support for Prometheus V1.1 hot end.
This support is made for Scalar M and Scalar XL 3D printers.
The Prometheus fan can stay on the hot end as the middle hole is properly sized.

The Hot end models are from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:302307
and are provided for information purpose only.

Updates:

08/16/2015: Add a 3rd hole for better stability on the X carriage

Have a great printing experience!

title: A new top-left motor support for SmartrapCore with more accurate height

description.text:
In its original shape, this support piece makes you put the geared wheel that drives the GT2 belt way too high on the axis. I designed this new one that allows to put the motor high enough to avoid this issue, and moves it a little bit backward because otherwise there's no way to have the left Y axis properly installed. That means you'll need a belt that's 2cm longer… I hope you had some extra length on the one you were using. ;)

Update (08/23/2015) : I added a slightly modified version (with an angle beveled), that might be more appropriate for certain configurations, for instance if you have a fanduct installed on the left, or to allow the use of a Bowden and wires guide if you need it to be on the left.

After the fifth time when the from-the-store, cheap plastic hook broke, I designed and made my own. I use it to hang my computer headset under my desk when I an not using it. The hook can be also used as a wire clip, to organize the wires. 
There are two versions, smaller 20x10mm and 30x15mm. The larger one is the one I am using for my Logitech USB headset. 
The part is designed using SolidWorks 2011

Download
Print
Cut the support, to open the hook
Cut a piece of a double-sided sticky tape and apply on the back. 3M thick double-sided tape works for me.
Attach under your desk, a bit away so you do not knock down the headset when you move your chair.
Enjoy your clutter free desk!

author: mtbox

description.text:
Geoffs_Simple_Spool_Restraint

A simple design I made to prevent the Filament spilling over the Spool's side & jamming the filament feed- it's very annoying and happens (to me !) when I have a very full (or loosely wound) Spool of filament.

The weight that prevents jamming can be anything - I used a scrap piece of Nylon (approx 10mm x 20mm x 300mm), but anything that's a similar size and slightly slippery could be used. For VERY FULL (overwound) spools I add a little extra weight - such as a couple of 1/2inch sockets, one on each vertical

I initially thought of extremely complicated kludges with springs and elastic, but settled on gravity as being much simpler - and it hardly ever fails :-)

description.text:
A lid for common baby jars in order to kill fruit flies. The jar should have a diameter of 50 mm with a height of about 9 mm. I used jars from HIPP. Fill the jar with about one finger height of vinegar and water (mix 1:1) and a droplet of dish soap (so the flies are drowning).

Eine Deckel für übliche Babygläschen, um Fruchtfliegen zu fangen. Das Gläschen wird dann mit 1 cm Essig/Wasser 1:1 Mischung und einem Tropfen Spülmittel gefüllt. Dann diesen Deckel drauf und dort hingestellt, wo die Fliegen sich aufhalten.

Fly picture curtsey of https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Datei:Drosophila_melanogaster_-_side_(aka).jpg

title: Adapter for Lido 2 and 3 coffee grinder.

description.text:
This adapter fits on top of the axle for the Lido 2-3 grinder. It has a through hole for the use of the OEM screw to hold it in place. The D shaped side fits to the axle. The other end is a hex shape, that is sized to use a 21mm metric socket.
Further iterations of this concept could include a gear or pulley for a belt, a motor or drive mechanism.
I used a 3d printer with ABS.

Quick Boat (not "swift boat" ;) for T-slots.

Grooves hold Cardboard sides.

Definition: A "boat" is used to contain chips when using a milling machine. This makes cleanup after a job much easier.

These two files are mirror configuration that allows you to print out 2 of each. Either the front and back cardboard or the left and right cardboard are cut to an angle of 15 degrees. the other two sides are "proud" of the angled sides. This will let you construct a quick variable size boat for CNC milling. I used these on a Central Machinery #47158 micro mill with a flashcut retrofit and littlemachinery collet set (not shown).

The boat is made to use disposable cardboard sides. You might want make a 15 degree guide for fast cutting the cardboard by hand or on a paper cutter.

Une série de chassis de 90,100,110 ou 120 mm au choix et les crashcage associées. Utilisables avec la carte du nano qx de blade et des moteurs coreless de 6 ou 7 mm. (type chaoli cl-... que vous pouvez trouver par exemple chez micro-motor-warehouse.com)
Il vous faut également des batteries 1s type "baton". (E Flite, Parkzone ...)
Sur les photos vous avez une version 90mm et une de 120mm. (les deux avec des moteurs cl-0615 de 11000kv) Toutes imprimées en PLA avec des couches de 0.3mm.
Evidemment c'est plus lourd qu'un chassis de nano qx d'origine. (difficile de faire plus léger en impression 3d)
Je vous conseille fortement d'appliquer un point de colle sur les cables des moteurs et entre les moteurs et le chassis. Histoire d'éviter qu'ils tournent sur eux mêmes et abiment les fils.
Noms des fichiers : 1er chiffre = taille des moteurs / les autre chiffres = taille du chassis. (exemple nanoquad6110 = moteurs de 6 mm / chassis de 110 mm )

description.text:

Finally clamp or secure the vice or blank in place and slide out the alignment tool. This will give you a quick alignment for 90 degrees to the milling machine's T-slot.

This is for "low tolerance" setups but seems to work very nicely.

UPDATE 11/8/15: Customiser's script rendering time limits of around 5 seconds are greatly inhibiting mould and fractal generation. As a result I have uploaded sample STLs instead of running through Customiser and I therefore recommend running the .scad file locally with openSCAD.

Simply download openSCAD (http://www.openscad.org/downloads.html), load the .scad file and press F6 to render models with any variables you like.

Fract-A-Castle is a completely customizable generator of sandcastle moulds described by 2D and 3D Julia set fractal patterns. It has never been easer to amaze onlookers with the beauty of mathematics.

The Idea

Fractals are perhaps one of the most strikingly beautiful areas of mathematics. Julia set fractal patterns like those in Fract-A-Castle may be generated from quadratic iterations. These iterations, such as z → z^2 + c, describe a process: take a complex number, square it, and add a constant complex number c. Repeating this process iteratively reveals a patterns known as Julia set, consisting of the set of all z on the complex plane such that z → z^2 + c does not diverge exponentially.

Through varying both the real and imaginary component of c, many different beautiful Julia set fractal patterns can be generated. I also conceived of generating 3D Julia set fractals, called capstones, each vertical level of which would be obtained from a higher number of quadratic iterations. The capstones would reveal visually how fractal patterns emerge, and are a great way to teach others about the beauty of complex dynamics.

Implementation

After a little tinkering around, I was eventually able to implement a Julia set fractal generator in openSCAD. This was quite challenging, especially with my fairly limited coding experience. I had to learn how to program at a functional as opposed to objective manner, and work with with the compile-time variables of openSCAD instead of the run-time variables of MATLAB and C. My final generator was achieved through a combination of recursion and pseudo-complex number representation.

The next step was building the fundamental basic designs we all associate with castles: walls, towers and battlements. I also incorporated a text mould generator to enable one to decorate or label their own fractals with text and Unicode characters.

Finally, I reworked and eliminated some of the more troublesome features of my designs for increased printability and ease-of-use with wet sand. The towers, for instance, were originally designed with customizable overhang angles, but it was very difficult to incorporate this feature with a sandcastle mould, which must be vertically convex to enable separation of sand from mould.

Result

Fract-A-Castle is the ultimate tool for demonstrating mathematical prowess at the beach. One can use large 2D fractal moulds like cookie cutters, leaving rows of fractal patterns in the sand. Three-dimensional capstones can be generated, enabling onlookers to better understand the emergence of fractal patterns over successive iterations. Finally, one can combine these fractals with a fully parametric classic castle design to add a new mathematical twist to the timeless art of sandcastles.

**Generating fractals and minkowski moulds in openSCAD is quite computationally exhaustive. For this reason, the resolution of fractal and capstone moulds defaults to low values to allow for preliminary rendering. I recommend identifying pretty Julia set pattern seeds with the help of the following website: http://www.easyfractalgenerator.com/julia-set-generator.aspx. After then getting the fractal sizing right, one can increase fractal resolution for final rendering and STL export.

If a pattern appears on the website but not on the Customizer app, try increasing the “modulus_threshold” variable under the “Fractals” tab.

Final mould renderings may take a few minutes, especially at higher resolutions. If lag on the Thingiverse is becoming unbearable, simply download the .SCAD file and generate models from the desktop.

Very high resolution fractals and capstones may not be generated watertight. This arises from the difficulty in correctly rendering both high and low-resolution fractals in one program. While this may not affect slicing, any non-watertight models can be repaired freely at https://netfabb.azurewebsites.net/, https://makeprintable.com/, or through desktop programs such as Meshlab or Netfabb**

Castle instructions

  1. Experiment with different castle heights, top square scales, tower wall thicknesses and battlement cutaway values to generate a castle body.

Note that if one desires to impress fractal patterns on the sides of the castle walls in a completely free-standing manner as shown in the preview, one should try to minimise the slope of these walls. This is most easily achieved through decreasing the height of the castle itself to a value below 7. Don't worry about the positioning of the fractal or text patterns, merely their size, as they will be printed separately.

  1. Change the “I_WantTo” variable to Generate a castle body mould. Actual mould generation may take a minute or two due to the reliance upon minkowski function mould generation. Processing time can be decreased by lowering $fs or running the .scad file locally.

  2. Scale the resultant moulds by a factor of 10 as openSCAD units are in millimetres.

  3. The moulds can be printed at fairly low resolution, e.g. 0.4mm. With very low bridging speeds and a high number of vertical shells, one may be able to print the model without support. Alternatively, one can try inverting the model and generating support structures for the tops of the non-battlement sections of the towers. No support will therefore be generated in the mould interior which will not disrupt any sand moulding.

My sandcastles were printed in PLA, with no infill.

  1. For thick mould walls and airtight prints, one should drill holes at the tops of the towers and through the battlements to enable the sand to easily be separated from the mould.

Fractal instructions

  1. Identify good Julia set fractal seeds using the following website: http://www.easyfractalgenerator.com/julia-set-generator.aspx.

  2. Under the “Generate a castle body mould” tab, vary fractal_scale_x and fractal_scale_y until the relative sizing of the fractal with respect to the rest of the mould and text is satisfactory. Remember to leave a clearance of 2*mould_width for the mould walls between the towers and the fractal Ignore if printing big fractal moulds for use independent of a castle.

  3. Increase the resolution of whichever fractal is desired, a good value is 80. Change the “I_Want_To” variable to Generate a fractal mould and go make a cup of coffee, as mould generation may now take a minute or two.

  4. If printing big fractals for use independent of a castle, one can now scale the entire model to nearly fill a build plate. One may have to decrease mould_width and re-render the design a few times to get the scaling right.

  5. Print the fractal. Layer heights of up to and including 0.4mm produced beautiful fractals. I don't recommend any infill for the moulds as they should merely be the walls themselves.

Capstone instructions

  1. Identify good Julia set fractal seeds using the following website: http://www.easyfractalgenerator.com/julia-set-generator.aspx.

  2. Change the “I_WantTo” variable to Preview a capstone. Enter the fractal seeds identified in step 1 and ensure that the pattern is appearing. Don't worry that the pattern appears extremely pixelated for the moment. Once again, If a pattern appears on the website but not on the Customizer app, try increasing the modulus_threshold variable under the “Fractals” tab.

  3. Change the “capstone_scale_x/y”, “capstone height” and “slices” variables until one is satisfied with the dimensions and overall emergence of the final capstone pattern.

  4. Increase the resolution of the capstone (one good value is 30) and change the “I_Want_To” variable to Generate a capstone mould. Go and make one or even two cups of coffee.

  5. Print the capstone. Infills of 30% can be used quite freely here. No support should be required. Layer heights are really dependent upon the value of “slices” and size of the capstone, though for large capstones, 0.4mm will do quite nicely.

title: Counter Rotating Propellers - proof of concept v.2

description.text:
For now, this is just a proof of concept of how couter rotating propellers can be driven. There are no complete mechanics to print yet. I am working on it.

Movement goes in at the red axle on the right, and through the hollow green axle. The Movement is reversed by the blue gears and goes out through the green axle.

See: https://youtu.be/dCCo4gIuark

The idea of counter rotating propellers is to cancel out the torque of only one propeller. Maybe an interesting enhancement for the Toypedo (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:932180) or other things like that?

Soft robotics is a new and young field of robots that uses (mostly) soft and compliant materials as opposed to rigid and hard materials. Most soft robots are composed of multiple soft robotic actuator, most of which are actuated by air. This project is an actuator that extends when inflated. The Instructables guide can be found here: http://www.instructables.com/id/Extending-Soft-Actuator/

Videos:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=72DSDvMXxP8
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=348WSyRwkCw

Here are the amounts of the different parts:

2x Outer.stl
1x Core.stl
1x Adapter.stl

I would recommend printing all parts in PLA or ABS at .2mm layer height with 3 shells.

How should we calculate a teoric sand castle internal efforts, and in consecuence, where would it collapse?
This answer, thinking it mathematly, should be the height where the castle has the highest pressure value, witch is calculated as weight over area.
Once we know this, it is easy to think about a mathematic designed castle, that has the same pressure for any height, optimizing that way its shape, and corresponding to gaudi's idea of beautifulness, when an structure has anything superfluous.
Once known this, the first step I made is to take a calc file and dispose the necesary data, in columns we have radio, squared radio, area, weight, pressure, in rows data will be show for every height, starting from up to downside.
Data is related in the calc file, so I start with an imaginary weight and a specific pressure (You can try changing value on E3 and F3). When it gets the neccesary area for divide that weight, it calculates the new weight, that will be the value for next iteration, so that way I get a radio value for every height millimeter by millimeter, what can be exported to design software.
Step number two is to choose a curve, I took the 0.111g/mm^2 one, and printed one small mold for testing it, and then I made the full design. It is important to test it because different sand tipe will resist different pressures. I made a render of five different castles so you can see a great range of forms with their design pressures.
The way I export this curve is just coping it and executing in Autocad with the word "pol" before (polyline), it shouldn't be difficult to modify this to make your one.
Third step was to make the a full sand tower, with aureal curves tessellated mold. This one is made in two 150mm height molds.
Final step was to make my full castle, with an squared wall, witch also has the isobaric curve form.
Finally I made two castle versions, 150mm and 300mm tall, called 1 and 2 respectively, but it could be personaliced by scalating molds.

Print all molds with bottom and perimeter.
It worked on my printer with just only one 0.7mm perimeter.
Maybe some pieces need brim.

I came across quite a few print-and-fly airplanes. personally i found that they were tough to print. Especially the wings. So here I introduce a completely different form of making the wing.

1. It is printed in vase print only (no more guessing infill percentages or playing with seam orientation)
  2. Print with single bottom layer and you get nice ribs and spar as supports.
  3. I used a 6mm and 3mm square CF tubes to strengthen. (You can very easily carry forward the concept to use round tubes/rods)
  4. Assembly is pretty straightforward using some CA.

The design is done in Sketchup. The source files included might look confusing. But all the parts (including the stages of development are in there!!)

Sorry for the bad photographs. My phone has been behaving strange!

title: Arduino Shield Modules for KiCad V3

description.text: This replaces the prior version. I added a version, "*_040pins", with larger pin holes to allow for larger non-stackable pins. The prior version works perfectly with female stackable header pins but not with many regular male pins. These are modules for both EESchema and PCBNew in KiCad. They will allow you to make PCBs that have the appropriate header positions for a Arduino shield. I adapted files I found on the KiCad yahoo group (http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/kicad-users/files/Library/ArduinoShield.ZIP posted by axtz4) adding a version for the MEGA. I have found many Eagle librarys but very few for KiCad, I hope this encourages others to use this great tool and share more KiCad files.
Add these files to your KiCad library & modules folders, add them to your project, and enjoy.

description.text: This is a 123D Catch scan of a statue on the corner of one of the buildings in the Pavillon Sully at the Louvre in Paris, France. Source data (photos, etc) available here: http://www.123dapp.com/FullPreview/Index.cfm/ID/1408098

I cleaned up the catch in Autodesk meshmixer, and generated support posts automatically. Files with and without support posts are included.   
I printed on a Replicator 2 with default "Medium" profile in MakerWare, with Raft enabled (necessary for the support posts to stick).  
The support posts are sized for the current print size (15cm length). If you scale the model with posts down, the posts will eventually become too small at the tip to connect, and you will get a mess.  
My print curled a lot, to the point where it pulled up my blue tape in one corner, and partially cracked the model. It may be better to print vertically. I have included a version with support posts in vertical orientation, sized to 10cm high, but have not tested this print.

title: paramchain: re-parametric OpenSCAD library  from Open Cable Chain

description.text:
Why one more cable chain?
I decided to add some cable chains to better control the cables position in my 3Drag. I start looking in Thingiverse for a "good" cable chain. My needs:
1) "open" because my 3Drag is now fully built.
2) "large" or parametric, because 3Drag uses flat cables.
I found some interesting designs, e.g. i tested http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:868040. But my printer was making large "spider webbing", calling for a long cleanning time for every element.... One more need:
3) "little work after printing".

The winner was 'Open Cable Chain' (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:611593), requiring very little work after printing.

But 'Open Cable Chain' is not large enough for my 3Drag flat cables, so I re-make this parametric library, starting from some .stl files by Claghorn.

The "paramchain" library builds open cable chain elements and chain ends having parametric size, in three options:
A type, rotating 0:45°, standard
B type, rotating -45°:0°, reverse of A
C type, rotating -45°:45° autoreverse

The open chain can be closed using bits of 3mm filament, or alternating normal and reverse elements.

To help the user, the type and size of any element is printed inside the element.

Notes:

Any element is 15 mm long, and rotates
45°: 8 elements make a circonference, diameter 53 mm

Modules:
chain_one(large, type)
chain_four(large, type)
end_one(large, type)

Parameters:
large: size external, 15 mm up. The internal chain space is: (large - 10.5) x 7.5 mm.

type:
= 0 => S, only for end_one (female start)
= 1 => A, 0:45° chain / end_one (male end)
= 2 => B, -45°:0° chain / end_one (male end)
= 3 => C, -45°:45° chain / end_one (male end)

note: this library (paramchain.scad) requires 2 model files by Claghorn: "nobar_one.stl", "end_two.stl".

Use:
1) If you prefere to use bits of 3mm filament to close the cables inside the chain, to get a standard chain you can use a sequence like:
S + A + A...+ A + end(A).
(the bits can be fixed using glue or the soldering iron).
2) If you do not like to use bits, you can alternate normal and revesed elements:
S + B + A + B... + A + B + end(A)
the cable is keep inside from elements structure.
3) To make a chain rotating in both directions, use C elements, autoreverse.
4) More complex designs, e.g. S-shaped chain, can be built using a mix of A, B, C types.

Printing:
I printed this in series of 4 (chain_four), more times to test different configurations and minimize the "spyder webbing" issue.
Using PLA ('esun' from Futura) and standard 3Drag 1.2 and Slic3r, my best results using:

  • bed: mirrow, 50°, no brim
  • temperature: 200°/175°
  • fan: 80%
  • layer: 0.2, infill: 100%
  • print speed: 30/60 mm/s
  • retraction: 3 mm at 60 mm/s, lift-z 0.3, travel speed 250 mm/s

title: UPDATED 2 Glass Clips for Printrbots - measured to include 2mm neoprene insulation PLEASE COMMENT

description.text:
Update 2: Bigger holes by 40% for screws and countersinks  
UPDATE:  This is the proper design, the previous version did not have enough depth for the g;ass plate.  I have also uploaded the sketchup file so you can adjust the depth of the overhang for printers without glass plates.  PLEASE COMMENT, then we know if we are doing the right thing! Thank you  
This set of 4 clips are for the 4 corners of the standard Printrbot LC 2 bed.  My heated bed has a sheet of 2mm neoprene and some aluminium foil under it for insulation do you will have to amend the stl if you are not using this.  The glass is standard 3mm window glass.  
If you need them, you can make the countersunks for the screws larger.  I have tried to keep the protrusion above the bed as low as possible while still being robust as my printer gets moved around a lot.  I suggest you knock 10mm off your x and y bed sizes in your printing software so you dont get a head crash.  
I have uploaded the original sketchup file as well as the stl.  I printed them  'upright' because of problems with delaminating when flat.  adjust as required  
The photo of two printed clips was V1, these are V2 and have a better shape plus a tapered top edge to reduce chances of head clashes.  
If your thinking why has he screwed down the bed when I have to remove my glass bed and chisel prints off it, thats because I am using the pipe cement detailed below and you just 'patch' the torn off cement after each use.. much easier....

Used a Printrbot LC V2 with a glass bed and plastic pipe adhesive to create a thin dried film on the glass bed to secure the parts*.  Printed with a 0.3mm layer height and standard infill settings.  
I set the nozzle temperature to 230 and the bed temperature to 90 as this works for me.  
Standard 3mm ABS from printrbot.  
To get a good grip between the clip and the glass surface, try coating the underneath of the clips where they contact the glass with rubber adhesive from a puncture repair kit  
*= Found that applying the pipe adhesive while the bed is heated gives best effect.  Three thin  coats at right angles to each other with a couple of seconds between for the last coat to dry from the heater and you get a slight weave of thicker 'skin' on the glass which holds really well but is easy to peel off the glass afterwards when you remove the pieces after printing

This is going to be a large church/temple type building for use in D&D. So far the bottom piece has been completed and I am working on the roof and bell tower.

I print with abs at 232 tip and 100 hot bed. Note if your printer is not enclosed there is a chance that some of the corners will warp and not adhere between some layers. This is due to the model being so large that by the time the printer makes it from one corner to the next the layer before may have cooled too much for the old layer and new layer to adhere to each other. So I recommend either splitting the model in half or finding a way to enclose your printer so the heat gets trapped a bit better.
