author: rambajs

remixed_from.author: kwyjibo
remixed_from.title: Magic Flight Finishing Grinder to Pax 2 Adapter

description.text:
Buy a high-quality print

Includes two funnels and three packing tools. Designed to snugly fit the Pax 2 vaporizer.

  • The larger funnel should fit a small grinder (with a diameter of 2" or 5cm).
  • The smaller funnel should fit a Magic Flight Finishing Grinder.
  • The first packing tool is designed to be used with either of the funnels.
  • The second packing tool is designed for standalone use.
  • The third packing tool is designed solely for the task of repacking the oven.

Another great way to repack the oven is to jam the funnel packer into the funnel to create a temporary bowl, then empty the oven onto the flat surface of the funnel tamper, and crush and spread the contents around using the Pax oven cover. Then just place the funnel into the Pax and remove the tamper.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Everything is printable as-is. I recommend using a larger raft for the standalone packing tools.

Regarding the repacking tool:

Why?

After each session, once the material has cooled, I repack the oven in order distribute the heat more evenly through the material. This can easily become a messy task.

The best way I've found to do it is to jam the funnel packer into the funnel to create a temporary bowl, then empty the oven onto the flat surface of the funnel tamper (usually by giving it a few solid taps), and crush and spread the contents around using the Pax oven cover. Then, I'd attach the funnel to the Pax and remove the tamper, allowing the material to funnel back into the oven, then repack.

However, the funnel and tamper are not fun to carry in your pocket, so I designed a more portable tool specifically for this task. It needed to act as a bowl to allow the material room to be stirred, but also allow a tamper to repack the material. I tried a couple ideas, and the better involved sliding the tamper and funnel together to form the bowl.

How?

Method 1: Put the fully assembled repacker in the Pax, turn it oven-end-down, and gently tap on a hard surface to loosen the material and allow it to fall into the repacker. Unfortunately, you won't be able to tell when the material has fallen into the repacker without carefully taking a potentially messy peek.

Method 2: Attach only the top part of the repacker to the Pax, then use a knife to break up the material. Attach the bottom part of the repacker, turn it oven-end-down, and give it a single, gentle tap.

Then: Once the material is inside the repacker, stir it up using the Pax oven cover (or a pen, pencil, knife, etc.). I also hold my finger over the opening and give it a few shakes. Then just re-attach the Pax, flip it, detach the repacker's bottom, and use its small end to re-pack the material. I recommend fully inserting and fully removing it a few times in order to allow all the material to fully funnel back into the oven.

remixed_from.author: sillano
remixed_from.title: paramchain: re-parametric OpenSCAD library  from Open Cable Chain

title: S-shaped parametric cable chain for 3Drag/K8200 extruder and chain end extension library.

description.text:
This cable chain for the 3Drag/K8200 printer extruder is builds using the "paramchain" library ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:963055 )

Here you can find the custom chain end library extension for 3Drag frame.

The chain is 40 cm long and 32 mm large. Using bits of 3mm filament, it is composed of:
1x 3Drag_start element (S type)
4x reversed element (B type)
18x standard element (A type)
1x 3Drag_end element (A type).

Choosing reversed elements to fix cables:
1x 3Drag_start element (S type)
2x reversed element (B type)
2x standard element (A type)
9x standard element (A type)
9x reversed element (B type)
1x 3Drag_end element (A type).

As you can see in photos, my wife chosed bits of 3mm filament to fix cables ("nicer" she said).

As extra, a rudimentary filament cutting helper.

Extruder chain:
The related stl files are:

  • two_3Drag_end_32.stl (requires support)
  • four_A_32.stl

  • four_B_32.stl

    For print info see "paramchain" library

Library (OpenSCAD):
Extension of "paramchain" library:
The 3Drag_end(large, type, hor) is a parametric module for custom version of basic chain end, to fix it to the 3Drag frame as usual, using a flat head 5M bolt and a square nut.

Parameters:
large: see "paramchain" library
type: see "paramchain" library
hor: true, the chain is parallel to frame
false, the chain is orthogonal to frame

note:
This libray requires "paramchain.scad" and base files: "nobar_one.stl", "end_two.stl", added here for your convenience.

extra:
To cut the 26 bits of 3mm filament having same length, I built a rudimentary cutting help. Maybe it can be useful, so i put it here too, in scad file (no stl) only as it needs adaptations.

author: beppemac

description.text:
The Go Pro Cage allows users of the popular Go Pro camera to safely mount their Go Pro cameras with open access to all buttons and the mic. What this means is anytime you wish to make a video with your Go Pro, you no longer get muffled noise provided by the standard waterproof casing. Instead crisp clear open audio since the mic is not covering by any casing. You can still get all around protection and great audio and video!

This design also means you don't always have to carry around the original bulky case with you everywhere. This Go Pro Cage is only 25% the weight of the standard waterproof case. This opens possibilities mounting this in situations where lighter materials are crucial, such as a quadcopter of small FPV aircraft.

This design also come with a 'blank' version where all you get if the base of the cage with no attachments, allowing users to customize their own way of attaching the cage to almost anywhere!

description.text:
remixed from 24mm arm (1806 motor) https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:304237

I have redrawn the part completely (STL is messy when imported) I Added room for 3x 5050 size Leds strip (60leds/m), eg WS2812.
Inside the closed part of the circle is a channel to feed thin wires into the tube (I used 0,25mm2) also increased motor vents at the bottom to give a bit more air to the motor windings

I added the solidworks source file for you to modify to fit your needs. note, this is WIP, Work In Progress

20150816 -> v2: (final)
made the openings a little bigger to ease the installation of the LEDs.

Sliced with Cura, 0,2mm layer @ 0.3mm nozzle average print speed. print without support

Tip, use ABS since motors can get warm, PLA will get soft and losen your screws.
